intro: Plocoglottis neohibernica, commonly known as the New Ireland fern, is a species of fern native to the island of New Ireland in the Bismarck Archipelago. It belongs to the family Blechnaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, lance-shaped fronds with a serrated margin. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as along stream banks and in forest undergrowth. Its rhizomes are fibrous and help anchor it to the substrate while facilitating nutrient absorption. The New Ireland fern is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and limited geographic distribution.
